Dear Mr. Gonzalez:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on April 4,
2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required.
The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed or
implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis

(1) There should be quarterly emergency fire
drills for each staff shift. Two of the drills shall
include evacuations, unless approved by the
department, in writing, as clinically

Fire drills were conducted quarterly but did not include each staff shift as it has

CCI Rule 400.4167 Case record maintenance
(1) The institution shall maintain a case record
for each resident.
Youth files were not maintained. Two of eight closed youth files reviewed did
not contain discharge reports for the youth. One youth's case closed 8/8/22
and another youth's case closed 10/28/22. These reports were printed on the
day of the audit, signed, and back dated. One of the reports had a note stating
the case manager was no longer with the agency and could not sign. One of
three open youth files did not contain a service plan completed every 15
calendar days after the first 30 calendar days. The 45-day after admission
report for one youth was due by 9/27/22 and was not in the file.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Case files need to be kept up to date, and documents should not be printed on
the day of the audit to satisfy the licensing requirements.
• Case files need to include signed reports by the case manager and case
manager supervisor. A few of the files reviewed had reports signed by the case
manager supervisor but there was a note the case manager was no longer
working there and could not sign. The agency admitted those reports were
printed the day of the audit, backdated, and put into the file.
• One open youth file did not contain a dental exam completed within 12 months
prior or 90 days after admission. The youth's dental exam was completed
12/15/22 & his admission date was 8/11/22. However, the agency provided
documentation the youth received a dental exam within 12 months prior the day
after the on-site inspection. The agency needs to make sure medical and dental
exam documentation for 12 months prior to admission follows the youth's file to
each CCI within Bethany Christian Services.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was not offered any consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The agency submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. The CAP was in response to nine
violations received during their 2022 Renewal Inspection. They have implemented
the CAP, and were able to resolve issues surrounding employee files containing
work history, job descriptions, education, references, TB testing and evaluations
within 180 days. Unfortunately, the facility was not able to fully resolve issues
5

surrounding criminal history checks for employees, central registry checks for
employees and youth files containing discharge reports as those are all violations
found during this Interim Audit period.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on a review of the facility’s budget
and the agency’s financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) reported most of the violations from the 2022 renewal
audit were a result of allowing federal employees to work in the facility due to low-
staffing levels at Bridgeway. During the last period, the facility was experiencing
many behavioral challenges with youth as well as language barriers due to a lack of
interpreters. CA reported during the 2022 audit period of review, they received a
violation surrounding missing discharge reports from youth files due to staffing
challenges within the case management team and miscommunications between
quality assurance personnel. CA reported the error was eventually caught and
corrected, however there were obviously still some discharge reports missed, which
caused a violation during this period of review as well. CA reported the
discontinued acceptance of federal volunteer workers in the program had a
significantly positive impact on rule compliance. CA reported they hold an "Annual
Day" which is a system wherein all staff members complete annual paperwork and
background checks, which has been largely successful in helping the program
remain in compliance with employee files for staff employed for longer than one
year. In addition, the facility has utilized a spreadsheet to track paperwork and
annual checks for all current employees, which has reportedly been helpful for the
facility given the size of Bridgeway's team. CA reported there were no unplanned
discharges during the reporting period. CA stated bi-weekly team meetings and
monthly direct care staff meetings will continue to occur throughout the year. During
the meetings, staff review policies and procedures, receive specialized training on
different topics related to working with the residents, make enhancements to
Bridgeway programming and ensure high quality service provision at all levels.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Employees interviewed reported they all felt very supported by other staff,
supervisors, and upper management at the facility. One employee reported they
are working on concerns with team dynamics as some team members are very
structured and others are very therapeutic, so they're trying to bridge the gap
between the two work styles. The employee reported there is a staff member who
took a 6–8-month journey away from the facility and learned about communication,
communication styles, etc. and is helping to be the neutral party to assist in these
improvements. Employees reported they are happy working at the facility, and they
feel there hasn't been a lot of staff turnover recently because it's such a great
6

environment to work in. Employees reported having two supervisors, two assistant
supervisors as well as staff who are willing to jump in and help whenever there are
crisis or stressful situations. Employees reported supervisors make time whenever
needed and they feel if/when they suggest changes or concerns, they feel they are
heard. They also feel they are supported in having an appropriate home-work life
balance. Employees feel the communication regarding changes, information, safety
needs, etc. is adequate and they feel having consistent biweekly meetings has
been very helpful. The only concern from employees was they wish the pay rate
could increase as the cost of living continues to increase.
All youth interviewed reported staff were nice and supportive. They reported they
had enough food at the facility and liked the food provided. They reported they felt
safe at the facility and felt all their needs were met. They reported they enjoyed
staying at the facility and did not have any concerns. They reported they didn't have
any changes they would like to see occur.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An on-site inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on April 4, 2023.
There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
